thread.title: Manchester City New Boy Gabriel Jesus Has Only Perfected One Mancunian Phrase
thread.title_full: Manchester City New Boy Gabriel Jesus Has Only Perfected One Mancunian Phrase

title: Manchester City New Boy Gabriel Jesus Has Only Perfected One Mancunian Phrase
text:
Manchester City New Boy Gabriel Jesus Has Only Perfected One Mancunian Phrase Tue Feb 07 2017 10:23:00   10:23:00 GMT+0000 (GMT) Josh Lawless Josh Lawless in football 
Manchester City new boy Gabriel Jesus's adaptation to English football is going swimmingly on the pitch. 
The Brazilian, signed for a Â£27 million from Palmeiras, has scored three goals in as many games in what has been a rapid start to life in the Premier League. 
He's led the line superbly and his form has been so good that he has managed to displace Sergio Aguero in attack, even Pep Guardiola has outlined his plans to pair the two together in the near future. 
As we know, it's typically incredibly difficult for overseas players to come in the Premier League and settle so quickly but Jesus is not continuing the trend with his impressive displays on the pitch. 
However, inevitably, the youngster has some learning to do off the pitch. 
In a bid to improve his communication with the rest of his teammates, Jesus has been listening to local radio stations such as BBC Radio Manchester to get up to speed with the dialect and slang used in these parts. 
Teammate Fernandinho, who now speaks English fluently, is said to have advised the striker to listen to the radio to improve his grasp of the language. 
But according to The Sun , the 19-year old has only managed to pick up and perfect the word "mate" so far. 
It's a promising start, because "mate" is easily the most important word in the English language but he's certainly got a long way to go before he becomes a true Mancunian. 
Becoming hooked on Coronation Street appears to be the next logical step, before he starts belting out Oasis songs and wearing a pair of Adidas Gazelles. 
By mastering mate, though, he already knows more English than Carlos Tevez, who spent seven years playing in the Premier League. 
Jesus appears to be the next big Brazilian talent, following on from the likes of Neymar and Ronaldinho. 
He just loves scoring goals and you see that in his facial expression every time the ball hits the back of the net. 
It's not too dissimilar to the reaction his fellow Brazilian Ronaldinho had when he scored his first ever goal for the Brazil national team in the Copa America. 
What a goal and what a celebration! Sponsored Links
